context: <a0_0><b5_0>Leading up to the American Civil War<b5_0/><a0_0/>, <b8_0>Baptists<b8_0/> became embroiled in the controversy over slavery in the United States. Whereas in <a1_0><b6_0>the First Great Awakening<b6_0/><a1_0/>, Methodist and Baptist preachers had opposed slavery and urged manumission, over the decades they made more of an accommodation with the institution. They worked with slaveholders in the South to urge a <a2_0><b7_0>paternalistic institution<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Both denominations made direct appeals to slaves and free blacks for conversion. <a3_0>The Baptists<a3_0/> particularly allowed them active roles in congregations. By the mid-19th century, northern Baptists tended to oppose slavery. As tensions increased, in <b9_0>1844<b9_0/> <a4_0>the Home Mission Society<a4_0/> refused to appoint a slaveholder as a missionary who had been proposed by Georgia. It noted that missionaries could not take servants with them, and also that the Board did not want to appear to condone slavery.
